description: From Old English peonie, peonia et al., from Latin paeōnia; later reinforced by Anglo-Norman peonie, Old French peone, from Latin paeōnia, from Hellenistic Ancient Greek παιωνία (paiōnía), from Ancient Greek Παιών (Paiṓn, “Paean, the physician of the gods”)/παιών (paiṓn, “a physician”).

entries.meaning: A flowering plant of the genus Paeonia with large fragrant flowers. [from 10th c.]
examples: The root of the Male Peony fresh gathered has been found by experience to cure the falling-sickness.
